entries.title: "Creeks Village (Miki's home)"
entries.body:
[[Miki (Eldrin)]]

After leaving the fallen warrens, Eldrin first arrives at a village within the mountains called Creeks Village. The village is well known for its creeks with water that heals the individuals. Tired from the journey, cookie & cream begs Eldrin to dip their small puffy feet in the creeks to rest. Eldrin agrees. However, the gate to the village is empty which raises suspicion. Eldrin, who feels the instinctive danger grabs his quarterstaff for a possible sudden attack.

Creeks village was quiet, as a cold current passed Eldrin. Eldrin realizes that the village was manifested by mana slimes, who drank all the creek water and became stronger than ever. Eldrin realizes that cookie & cream are in grave danger, as he cannot protect them fully from the slimes. They run towards the gate, just to be blocked by the manipulating slimes. Eldrin uses his staff to explode the slime from the core, however the slime heals right away due to the creek's water. Eldrin puts a protective spell on cookie & cream and uses his staff to grow trees that make a wall in between. The slime absorbs the trees and melts them inside. While so, two of the slimes sneak attacks on Cookie & Cream and absorbs them. However, something both the slimes and Eldrin didn’t expect happens. Cookie & Cream on the other hand absorbs the slimes, and the slimes can’t escape due to the protection shields that Eldrin put beforehand. Cookie & Cream earn the slime’s abilities and can eat anything from small objects to steel metals. Eldrin eventually realizes that Cookie & Cream can also heal endlessly, but that is another story.

entries.title: "The Birth of O-Block: The Dark Legacy of Elverdeen"
entries.body:
**

The Black Market of the Continent of Azterra

### The Birth of O-Block: The Dark Legacy of Elverdeen

Three centuries ago, in the heart of the grand city of Elverdeen, King Varros the Ever-Ambitious sat upon his throne, consumed by a single, desperate obsession—eternal life. He was a ruler of unmatched cunning, a master of war and politics, yet all his power was meaningless against the relentless march of time. As his body aged and his strength waned, he scoured the lands of Azterra for a cure to mortality.

Among the many forbidden answers he uncovered, one stood above the rest: the hearts of elves. Their unnaturally long lifespans were said to hold the secret to delaying death itself. At first, Varros sent his royal hunters to harvest these organs in secret, raiding elven villages under the guise of border skirmishes. But as his need grew more urgent and his body continued to wither, he abandoned subtlety altogether.

Instead of outlawing the trade of elf hearts, he allowed a black market to fester in the underbelly of Elverdeen. What began as a handful of desperate traders dealing in stolen organs soon became something far greater. Smugglers, assassins, slavers, and alchemists flocked to the city's forgotten districts, carving out a lawless realm known as O-Block—short for the “Organ Block,” named for the dark trade that birthed it.

Varros never found his immortality. Despite consuming countless elixirs distilled from elven hearts, he died at the age of 67—a husk of a man, twisted and broken by his own obsession. But the black market he had nurtured did not perish with him.

Over the centuries, O-Block grew beyond its grim origins. The trade of elf hearts remained, but it became just one piece of a vast underground empire. Cursed relics, stolen artifacts, forbidden tomes, poisons, and even creatures from the depths of Azterra’s most twisted corners—all found their way through O-Block’s labyrinthine alleys. It became a city within a city, governed by its own ruthless lords, where gold and blood were the only laws that mattered.

Now, 326 years later, O-Block is stronger than ever. Even the rulers of Elverdeen dare not challenge its dominion. Kings have come and gone, but the black market remains—an immortal legacy of the man who sought to defy death and instead gave birth to something far darker.

### The Shadow Spreads: O-Block Across Azterra

Though O-Block was born in the heart of Elverdeen, it did not remain confined to its streets for long. As the centuries passed, its influence spread like a creeping plague, reaching into every major human city across Azterra. Wherever there was gold to be made from forbidden trade, O-Block took root.

In [NAME 1], a city known for its sprawling docks and lucrative maritime trade, O-Block’s presence thrives in the form of smugglers who move illicit goods under the cover of legitimate shipping companies. Here, rare magical artifacts, stolen relics, and contraband alchemical substances change hands in candlelit backrooms, their origins buried beneath layers of false records.

In [NAME 2], where the noble class revels in excess and indulgence, O-Block has woven itself into high society. Assassins, poisoners, and flesh traders cater to the dark desires of the elite, while secret auctions offer cursed treasures and forbidden knowledge to those willing to pay in blood. Even the city’s most powerful lords whisper the name O-Block with a mix of fear and admiration, knowing that the hand that feeds them today may slit their throat tomorrow.

In [NAME 3], a city built atop ancient ruins, O-Block’s trade is in secrets. Forgotten tomes, lost spells, and artifacts of terrifying power flow through hidden vaults beneath the streets. The city’s scholars and mages often find themselves entangled in its dealings, some willing participants, others trapped in debts they can never repay.

Now, O-Block is more than a district—it is an empire of crime spanning Azterra. Each city’s branch operates with a degree of independence, adapting to local conditions, yet all remain connected through a vast network of smugglers, informants, and enforcers. Gold, blood, and power flow endlessly through its veins, ensuring that no ruler, no law, and no force of nature can ever truly erase it.

O-Block was born from the ambition of a dead king. Now, it belongs to the world.

  
  
  
  

### The Lords and Factions of O-Block

O-Block is not a monolith—it is a shifting web of power, ruled by factions and lords who each hold dominion over different aspects of the black market. While some work together in uneasy alliances, others are locked in silent wars, their conflicts fought in blood and gold beneath the notice of kings and emperors.

#### 1. The Bloodied Veil (Assassins & Enforcers)

The Bloodied Veil is the silent blade of O-Block, a network of assassins, enforcers, and bounty hunters who enforce contracts with ruthless efficiency. No one truly knows who leads them, for their highest members hide behind masks of flayed skin, a reminder of their first kill. Payment is accepted in gold, secrets, or life debts—those who cannot pay often find themselves recruited into the Veil, trained in the ways of silent execution. Their motto is simple: Death is a currency all men will one day spend.

#### 2. The Gilded Maw (Smugglers & Contraband Dealers)

If there is something illegal to be moved, the Gilded Maw will get it where it needs to go. This faction specializes in smuggling, moving everything from enchanted weapons to entire kidnapped noble families across borders unseen. Their influence runs deepest in [NAME 1], where their control over the docks ensures that not a single ship enters or leaves without their knowledge. Their leader, known only as Lord Harrow, is said to have a ledger detailing every illicit transaction in Azterra—a ledger no one has ever seen and lived to speak of.

#### 3. The Ebon Ledger (Relic Traders & Forbidden Knowledge)

O-Block is not just about physical goods—knowledge is power, and no one understands this better than the Ebon Ledger. This faction deals in stolen tomes, lost spells, and artifacts too dangerous for the world above. Their members are scholars and occultists, willing to trade secrets in exchange for even darker truths. The leader of the Ledger is Master Quell, an ancient figure rumored to have lived for over a century, sustained by the very artifacts he sells.

#### 4. The Crimson Tide (Flesh Trade & Slave Lords)

The Crimson Tide deals in flesh—willing or otherwise. Slavery is their primary business, but their influence extends to gladiator pits, body modifications, and exotic transformations using alchemical or magical means. Their most grotesque operations involve elf hearts, a trade that has never fully died since the days of King Varros. Their leader, Madame Nyza, is a former noblewoman whose body is stitched together from countless donors, her youth and power preserved at a terrible cost.

#### 5. The Rot-Touched (Monstrous Entities & Experimental Alchemy)

Nowhere is O-Block’s adaptability more evident than in Kyrathys, where the Rot-Touched thrive. This faction specializes in the capture, study, and manipulation of monstrous entities—particularly slimes. They have found ways to use the creatures as weapons, as enforcers, and even as alchemical resources. Their leader, Doctor Ylric, is a former mage who was consumed by a sentient slime and now exists in a half-dissolved state, his body shifting between human and ooze. He speaks through a mouth that is never in the same place twice, whispering of a future where the living and the formless become one.

### The Unseen Hand: The Hidden Lords of O-Block

Though the factions wage war and strike deals, there is whispered talk of greater forces pulling the strings. Some believe O-Block itself is ruled by an unseen council, figures who have remained in power for centuries, their influence stretching across Azterra. Others claim that the market serves something even darker—an entity that does not trade in gold, but in something far more valuable.

For those who rule O-Block, wealth is only a means to an end. Power, after all, is the only currency that never devalues.

  
  
  
  
**

entries.title: "Main Timeline"
entries.summary: - **Cause**: The death of the dragons created an immense imbalance, leaving many nations scrambling for dominance.
entries.body:
- **Cause**: The death of the dragons created an immense imbalance, leaving many nations scrambling for dominance.
    
- **Major Players**:
    
    - **Elven Kingdom**: Initially losing but turned the tide thanks to the Knight of Kaya.
        
    - **Dwarven Clans**: Fought for lost magical artifacts but ultimately suffered great losses.
        
    - **Orcs & Dragonborn Tribes**: Allied in an effort to restore balance but failed.
        
- **Aftermath**:
    
    - The war created long-lasting resentment and instability.
        
    - The Knight of Kaya, rather than being honored, was feared and resented by both sides.
        
    - The dwarves' greatest artifacts were stolen or vanished into the void.
        
    - The rise of secret factions seeking to manipulate the divine balance left behind by the fallen gods.
        
    - Growing whispers of Krovi’s return as old cults emerge from hiding.

entries.title: Druid (Circle of the Shrine) Level 2
entries.summary:
## **Druid ([Circle of the Shrine](https://dnd5e.wikidot.com/druid:land)) Level 2**
#### **Spell Modifiers:**
- Spell Casting Ability (+4)
	- Adds to the “to-hit” roll of a spell or cantrip
- Spell Save DC (14)
	- Used for enemy’s Saving Throw threshold (if enemy doesn’t have more than the Spell Save DC, it will be affected by the spell/cantrip)
- Spell Attack Bonus (+6)
	- Adds to the “damage” roll of a spell, but not to cantrips
---
#### **Cantrips (3):**
- ###### Guidance
	- Divination cantrip
	- Casting Time: 1 action
	- Range: Touch
	- Components: V, S
	- Duration: Concentration, up to 1 minute
	- You touch one willing creature. Once before the spell ends, the target can roll 1d4 and add the number rolled to one ability check of its choice. It can roll the die before or after making the ability check. The spell then ends.
- ###### Water's Will
	- Transmutation cantrip
	- Casting Time: 1 action / 1 bonus action
	- Range: 30 feet
	- Components: V, S, M (5 gallons of water)
	- Duration: 1 minute
	- You move water to assist yourself or a willing creature. Before starting an action / bonus action / saving throw / movement that they want assistance on, the target may roll 1d4 and add that number to one of the following. 
		- To-hit roll of any physical projectile
		- Damage roll of any physical projectile
		- Dexterity saving throw
		- Movement:
			- Rolling 1 or 2 grants the target 10 feet of extra movement
			- Rolling 3 or 4 grants the target 15 feet of extra movement
	- The target must choose whether they want assistance / assistance type before rolling the 1d4. If the target chose to have assistance, then after their turn ends, this cantrip and its effects end.
	- This cantrip may only be casted as a bonus action if it is to be casted directly after creating water from the spell "Create or Destroy Water."
- ###### Magic Stone
	- Transmutation cantrip
	- Casting Time: 1 bonus action
	- Range: Touch / 60 feet
	- Components: V, S
	- Duration: 1 minute
	- You touch one to three pebbles and imbue them with magic. You or someone else can make a ranged spell attack with one of the pebbles by throwing it or hurling it with a sling. If thrown, it has a range of 60 feet. If someone else attacks with the pebble, that attacker adds your spellcasting ability modifier, not the attacker’s, to the attack roll. On a hit, the target takes bludgeoning damage equal to 1d6 + your spellcasting ability modifier. Hit or miss, the spell then ends on the stone.
	- If you cast this spell again, the spell ends early on any pebbles still affected by it.
---
#### **Spells (checked box = prepared):**
- Prepared: 6 (Druid level + Wisdom modifier)
- **Speak with Animals (Level 1) (always prepared)**
	- 1st-level divination (ritual cast = +10 minutes)
	- Casting Time: 1 action  
	    Range: Self  
	    Components: V, S  
	    Duration: 10 minutes
	- You gain the ability to comprehend and verbally communicate with beasts for the duration. The knowledge and awareness of many beasts is limited by their intelligence, but at minimum, beasts can give you information about nearby locations and monsters, including whatever they can perceive or have perceived within the past day. You might be able to persuade a beast to perform a small favor for you, at the DM’s discretion.
- [x] **Zżweaż wol Ezþażwżo / Prayer of Azterra (Level 1)**
	- 1st-level divination (ritual cast = +10 minutes)
	- Casting Time: 1 action
	- Range: 30 feet
	- Components: V, S
	- Duration: Concentration, up to 1 minute
	- You utter an ancient prayer to the land, invoking a force of nature. With this forgotten prayer, a wave of natural energy emanates from you to restore vitality and reinforce the bond between nature and its protectors.
	- When the spell is initiated, you and any allies within 30 feet gain temporary hit points equal to 1d4 + your spellcasting ability modifier. In addition, you and any ally that is touching natural ground heal for 1d4 hit points.
	- At Higher Levels. When you cast this spell using a spell slot of 2nd level or higher, the temporary hit points increase by 2 per slot level, and the healing increases by 1d4.
- [x] **Þwep Żalażzwuð / Time Reversal (Level 1)**
	- 1st-level abjuration
	- Casting Time: 1 action
	- Range: 60 feet
	- Components: V, S, M (objects/creatures to reverse time on)
	- Duration: Instantaneous
	- Using this ancient druidic spell, you reverse time in order to gain a more favorable course of events. This spell allows the target to retry their most recent action and bonus action if applicable. The target may not change their attacks/cantrips/spells cast.
	- At Higher Levels. When you cast this spell using a spell slot of 2nd level or higher, the target becomes able to change their attacks/cantrips/spells cast during the reversed action. At slot level 3+, the target’s action gets advantage on 1 roll of their choosing (if applicable), +1 roll with advantage for each level above 3.
- [x] **Create or Destroy Water (Level 1)**
	- 1st-level transmutation
	- Casting Time: 1 action  
	- Range: 30 feet  
	- Components: V, S, M (a drop of water if creating water or a few grains of sand if destroying it)  
	- Duration: Instantaneous
	- You either create or destroy water.
		- Create Water. You create up to 10 gallons of clean water within range in an open container. If no such open container is present, only up to 5 gallons of water may be created, in which this water orbits around you. Alternatively, up to 10 gallons of water falls as rain in a 30-foot cube within range, extinguishing exposed flames in the area.
		- Destroy Water. You destroy up to 10 gallons of water in an open container within range. Alternatively, you destroy fog in a 30-foot cube within range.
	- At Higher Levels. When you cast this spell using a spell slot of 2nd level or higher, you create or destroy 10 additional gallons of water (5 additional gallons for no container), or the size of the cube increases by 5 feet, for each slot level above 1st.
- [x] **Healing Word (Level 1)**
	- 1st-level evocation
	- Casting Time: 1 bonus action
	- Range: 60 feet
	- Components: V
	- Duration: Instantaneous
	- A creature of your choice that you can see within range regains hit points equal to 1d4 + your spellcasting ability modifier. This spell has no effect on undead or constructs.
	- At Higher Levels. When you cast this spell using a spell slot of 2nd level or higher, the healing increases by 1d4 for each slot level above 1st.
- [x] **Cure Wounds (Level 1)**
	- 1st-level evocation
	- Casting Time: 1 action
	- Range: Touch
	- Components: V, S
	- Duration: Instantaneous
	- A creature you touch regains a number of hit points equal to 1d8 + your spellcasting ability modifier. This spell has no effect on undead or constructs.
	- At Higher Levels. When you cast this spell using a spell slot of 2nd level or higher, the healing increases by 1d8 for each slot level above 1st.
- [x] **Ice Knife (Level 1)**
	- 1st-level conjuration
	- Casting Time: 1 action
	- Range: 60 feet
	- Components: S, M (a drop of water or piece of ice)
	- Duration: Instantaneous
	- You create a shard of ice and fling it at one creature within range. Make a ranged spell attack against the target. On a hit, the target takes 1d10 piercing damage. Hit or miss, the shard then explodes. The target and each creature within 5 feet of the point where the ice exploded must succeed on a Dexterity saving throw or take 2d6 cold damage.
	- At Higher Levels. When you cast this spell using a spell slot of 2nd level or higher, the cold damage increases by 1d6 for each slot level above 1st.
---
#### **Features:**
- **Gambler’s Ambition**
	- Before every cantrip and spell, you must flip a coin. If it lands heads up, your next cantrip/spell gains +1 damage (if it hits). If it lands tails, your next cantrip/spell instead loses 1 damage (if it hits). This effect stacks. The damage buff/nerf resets after either a Short Rest or Long Rest.
	- The amount of damage gained/loss increases by 1 when a new even Druid Level is reached (4, 6, 8, etc).
- **Druidic**
	- You know Druidic, the secret language of druids. While learning this ancient tongue, you also unlocked the magic of communicating with animals; you always have the Speak with Animals spell prepared. You can speak the language and use it to leave hidden messages. You and others who know this language automatically spot such a message. Others spot the message's presence with a successful DC 15 Wisdom (Perception) check but can't decipher it without magic
- **Wild Shape: 2 uses left**
	- The power of nature allows you to assume the form of an animal. As a Bonus Action, you shape-shift into a Beast form that you have learned for this feature (see “[Known Forms](https://www.dndbeyond.com/classes/2190878-druid)”). You stay in that form for a number of hours equal to half your Druid level or until you use Wild Shape again, have the Incapacitated condition, or die. You can also leave the form early as a Bonus Action.
	- Number of Uses. You can use Wild Shape twice. You regain one expended use when you finish a Short Rest, and you regain all expended uses when you finish a Long Rest.
- **Circle of the Shrine**
	- Bonus Cantrip. When you choose this circle at 2nd level, you learn one additional druid cantrip of your choice. This cantrip doesn’t count against the number of druid cantrips you know.
	- Natural Recovery. Starting at 2nd level, you can regain some of your magical energy by sitting in meditation and communing with nature. During a short rest, you choose expended spell slots to recover. The spell slots can have a combined level that is equal to or less than half your Druid Level (rounded up), and none of the slots can be 6th level or higher. You can't use this feature again until you finish a long rest.
		- Uses left:
			- [x] 1 use left
			- [ ] 0 uses left
---
#### **Orc Traits:**
- **Adrenaline Rush** (2 uses per long rest)
	- Uses left:
		- [x] 2
		- [ ] 1
		- [ ] 0
	- You can take the Dash action as a bonus action. You can use this trait a number of times equal to your proficiency bonus, and you regain all expended uses when you finish a long rest.
	- Whenever you use this trait, you gain a number of temporary hit points equal to your proficiency bonus.
- [x] **Relentless Endurance** (1 use per long rest)
	- When you are reduced to 0 hit points but not killed outright, you can drop to 1 hit point instead. Once you use this trait, you can’t do so again until you finish a long rest.

entries.title: Background
entries.summary:
###### Chapter 1: The Cavern
“Detonating charge in 3, 2, 1!” The sound from the large explosion echoes between the vast walls of Vasrið’s cave. 
“Watch out!” shouts one of the cavers. The demolitionists flee the scene as one of the wooden pillars begins to collapse. Like dominoes, more of the structure falls, with rubble from the cave following. The rocks cascade down through the tunnels.
entries.body:
###### Chapter 1: The Cavern
“Detonating charge in 3, 2, 1!” The sound from the large explosion echoes between the vast walls of Vasrið’s cave. 
“Watch out!” shouts one of the cavers. The demolitionists flee the scene as one of the wooden pillars begins to collapse. Like dominoes, more of the structure falls, with rubble from the cave following. The rocks cascade down through the tunnels.

🍎π stood frozen, watching the scene unfold before him.

Time stopped. The world around him froze. His parents stood there unaware of their impending doom. And in an instant; everything became nothing. 

The panicked orcs scurried around the area, ensuring that everything was okay. The dust swirled thickly in the air, clouding the once clear pathways of Vasrið’s cave. The sound of rubble shifting and heavy breathing echoed as a few cavers, unscathed but shaking, dug into the pile of debris. The smell of dirt and stone mixed with the faint scent of blood. The sunken weight in the chest of the young orc, still only 9 years old, was palpable.

"Faster, we need to get them out!" a voice barked, strained with urgency. Pi couldn’t hear the command over the cries that seemed to circle around him. The echoes of the explosion still lingered in his ears.

His mother’s face… his father’s laugh. Those were the last memories he had of them, and now they were buried under hundreds of tons of stone.

"Pi, we have to move!" Grazkul’s voice cut through the haze of his thoughts. The young orc's eyes snapped to his best friend, the only face in the chaos that was familiar. Grazkul, an aspiring architect, had been his friend for as long as he could remember. His eyes were filled with concern, but his voice was firm, pushing through the grief. "Pi, please! We need to help!"

For a moment, all 🍎π could do was stare at the pile of rocks, unsure whether he could face the reality of what was happening. But Grazkul’s hand on his shoulder grounded him. Taking a deep breath, he turned to the task at hand. They would dig, they would try to save those still trapped, even if the task felt hopeless. 

Every shift of the stone was a cruel reminder of the fragility of life. Eventually, the cavers uncovered the bodies of his parents. His mother, a formidable orcish woman who had always known what to say to ease his fears, now lay motionless in the rubble. His father, a stoic figure who had taught him the ways of survival in the harsh landscape, was gone too.

Pi gently placed his palm around his father’s chest, feeling a nostalgic warmth. They would not be coming back. A faint whisper from inside his mind: “you could’ve saved them…” The grief hit him like a wave. His body trembled as he fell backwards, his mind blanking for a moment. Grazkul, sensing the weight of the loss, placed his hand on Pi's arm. “We’ll get through this, together. We always have.”

Those words, though meant to comfort, only deepened the ache. Still, there was a part of him that clung to them. His friend was right. Together, they had always persevered. But now, with the loss of his parents, Pi felt the loss of a part of himself. The child he had been was gone. He was alone, or at least, that’s what it felt like.

###### Chapter 2: The Path Ahead
Years passed. Time healed some wounds but never all of them. With no immediate family left, Pi moved in with Grazkul. Their family wasn’t very rich, so all he brought was nothing but his bare necessities and his lucky coin that his parents gave him when he was younger. 

At 12, when the orcs reached adulthood, Pi and Grazkul moved to Każþarim, a bustling city known for its rapid growth and constant demand for labor. The city offered work, and for a time, the routine of building structures and managing the flow of materials kept Pi's mind from lingering on the pain of loss.

But there was always the pull of something more, something greater than the mundane work of the city. Something in Pi stirred—a hunger to explore, to understand, to break free from the repetitive motions of his life. The cave had once been his world, and now the vastness of the land seemed too big to ignore.

Grazkul, ever the practical one, had already begun to build his own reputation as a talented architect. But Pi, with his innate connection to the land and its untamed power, began to sense something calling to him beyond the walls of Każþarim. The strange whispers, faint at first, began to grow louder, and with them, a compulsion.

There was something in nature that had always felt alien to him. Growing up in the caves, surrounded by rock, darkness, and the occasional flicker of firelight, nature itself had been a mystery—something he had only seen in rare glimpses through the cracks in the earth. But now it beckoned, in ways that no one else could seem to hear.

In time, Pi's ambition drove him to answer that call. The voices, those mysterious whispers that had begun as subtle thoughts in his mind, now pushed him to seek out answers. Why did they call to him? What were they? Where did they come from?

Despite his growing expertise as a builder and laborer, he couldn’t shake the feeling that he was meant for something more. 

And so, with a heavy heart but an unshakable will, Pi set out to uncover the mysteries of the voices that seemed so tied to his soul, his past, and his very existence. In doing so, he found himself on the path of a druid. The land, the trees, the winds, and the rivers—they were all alive in ways he had never understood before. 

###### Chapter 3: Decision
Pi wandered far from Każþarim, to the edges of forests and deep into the wilds. His draw to nature only grew with each passing day. The voices grew louder, clearer. He had no idea what they were saying, only that they wanted him to do something. They would only say one chant: “Wto Zweżwofinz Żrwev wol Ezþażwżo”

As an avid gambler, Pi would often drop by at any tavern he saw. He would feel the texture of the cards, the edges of the dice, sensations he had felt many times. But his mind wandered; it wandered further than his travels. The voices’ decision.

A call, a shriek, a cry for more. Pi knew that the voices were getting restless, despite never having understood them. What did they want? Who were they? Questions only led to more questions. In the 20 years since the accident, since the voices’ birth, Pi had never told anyone else about the voices, not even Grazkul. He tried to ignore them and focus on his current game.

Like always, Pi relied on his lucky coin in his gambling. He let it dance around his fingers before flicking it up into the air. The coin reflected the sun’s rays as it spun before falling back into his palm heads up. Pi was all in. 

Session 1
Session 2

###### Chapter 4: A Whisper of Power

The sun was setting, casting an orange glow over the water as it rushed past, winding its way between the jagged stones. The voices continued to call him, luring him farther into the misty forest, with leaves refracting rainbows of light. As he trotted through the textured ground, of small pebbles, soil, and colorful liquid, he noticed a certain tree. The tree was less vibrant than its neighbors, despite clearly being of the same species. He approached the unique form, standing at roots.

A blinding light flashed. Then darkness.

...

Pi decided to take a stroll around in the forests of Każþarim, and after about 15 minutes or so, Pi found himself standing before a sizable tree. The trunk was hollow, and it’s roots reached far, at least 30 feet. The ground shook, and the roots shifted to reveal an escalator leading down deep underground. Pi cautiously entered, knowing that this must be where the voices wanted him. It was the tree from his dream.

The shrine was quite spacious–it housed a clear lake with a small shrine in the center. Pi looked around the serene sanctuary, noticing the old and deteriorating writing on the walls. Since it was getting late, he made a mental note to come back later.

As he walked back home, he realized that the elements around him would respond with the faintest of rustles. Out of curiosity, Pi wondered if he could learn to control the reactions of nature. He began by slowly waving his hand over a small stream. Pi closed his eyes, letting the energy of the water fill his senses. His fingers hovered just above the surface of the stream, almost instinctively reaching out.

He focused on the water moving beneath him. He could feel the motion and direction of the clear lifeblood in his palm, even though he was still as a statue. 'How nice it must be, to let go and be able to drift on without worry,' he thought.

With that simple thought, Pi extended his hand and willed the water to shift. At first, nothing happened. He tried again, this time more deliberately, focusing all of his attention on the way the stream wound around the rocks.

And then, to his surprise, the water around his hand seemed to slow. It didn’t move dramatically, but it responded to his touch. A slight, fluid ripple danced where his fingers hovered, as if the water itself was aware of his presence. Pi’s breath caught. 

He tried again, reaching his arm out to the stream, holding out both hands this time. He closed his eyes and focused, envisioning the water lifting, flowing in response to his will. Slowly, steadily, the surface of the water rippled, forming a small wave that surged toward him before falling back into the stream.

###### Chapter 5: The Shrine
As days became and weeks and weeks became months, Pi found himself spending more time in nature and less time gambling. Even though he would be by himself–something he would typically avoid–now it felt different. He decided today to revisit the shrine.

With nothing to distract his thoughts as he walked, he remembered that day, the day that shook his soul. He remembered his father and his teachings of the land–how nature’s will is stronger than any being. Maybe this was why he felt drawn to nature.

Pi arrived at the shrine, with everything exactly as he remembered–the walls still undecipherable. Pi centered himself in the peaceful construct and relaxed. However, his rest was promptly interrupted by the voices. 

"This place remembers you, even if you don’t."
"Do you feel it? The moment where time bends?"
"Wþo Wpotaż vweþaż evf lwużzaz wovwaðfuvs, lwe wloża zrważuþ dwa luðf yut wtoża zewyoż wovavfuvs."

'Moment where time bends? What does that mean?' Pi asked himself, 'How does this place know me?'

The voices repeated their chorus once more. Pi felt a shock from his chest. He looked around at the writing on the walls of the shrine, only this time, he could read some of it. He read aloud the first line on the wall; it stood out the most and had stood the test of time:

"Wþo Wpotaż vweþaż evf lwużzaz wovwaðfuvs, lwe wloża zrważuþ dwa luðf yut wtoża zewyoż wovavfuvs." (To mother nature and forces unyielding, may my spirit be filled with thy power unending.)

The ground beneath him stirred, as if it was awakened after an eon's slumber. Pi felt a rejuvanating energy pulse twice through the air.

He realized that that was what the voices were saying. He looked up at the ceiling, where an inscription lay: “Wto Zweżwofinz Żrwev wol Ezþażwżo” (The Paradox Shrine of Azterra). The voices were calling him here. ‘But why?’ Pi wondered.

Pi continued reading the ancient writing on the walls, slowly deciphering the powerful markings:

"Wþo lażzþ þavaþ addz evf ðlwuz; wþo zwożz wol ðwul teþ wnopz evf swuz"
(The first tenet ebbs and flows; the source of life that comes and goes.)

In an instant, water arose from the lake. It twisted in the air and circled swiftly around the tree. The water formed a ring around the top of the tree, like a halo. The light from above casted down to refract in beautiful, shining rays. 

Pi heard the voices invite him:

"Zþar lwożt, wwovs żrwud; wfo vuþ dwa swu."
(Step forth, young druid; do not be shy.)

With courage, Pi stepped onto the lake, the water rippling beneath him. The water once circling the tree began to instead orbit above his head. Pi reached up to feel this magical fluid. When he touched it, the form focused on his hands and fingers. Pi brought the water in front of him and held it steady with both hands. It swayed and danced in loops, never stopping.

###### Chapter 6:

entries.title: Shrine Magic
entries.body:
---

---
#### **Spell Modifiers:**
- Spell Casting Ability (+4)
	- Adds to the “to-hit” roll of a spell or cantrip
- Spell Save DC (14)
	- Used for enemy’s Saving Throw threshold (if enemy doesn’t have more than the Spell Save DC, it will be affected by the spell/cantrip)
- Spell Attack Bonus (+6)
	- Adds to the “damage” roll of a spell, but not to cantrips
--- 
#### Cantrips:
- **Whisper of the Self**
	- 1 use, resets after one Short Rest or one Long Rest
		- [x] 1 use left
		- [ ] 0 usses left
	- Divination
	- Casting Time: 1 action
	- Range: Self
	- Duration: Instant
	- A faint, echoing voice murmurs suggestions...
	- You hear a brief whisper from ---------, granting you insight. Once before your next turn, you can reroll one ability check and take either result.
---
#### Spells:
- **Gossamer Veil (Level 1)**
	- 1st-level Transmutation
	- Casting Time: 1 action
	- Range: Self
	- Duration: 10 minutes
	- Your body shimmers like silk in the wind, allowing you to pass through tiny cracks, bars, or vines for 10 minutes. This effect does not make you intangible—your form simply adapts like flowing mist.

| +1 | | Survival (Wis) | +4 | ### Quick Info ###### Basic Info - Character Name: 🍎π - Race: Orc - Class: Druid - Subclass (if known): Circle of the Land - Alignment: Chaotic Neutral - Age & Gender: 31M - Height & Weight: 6'6", 314 lbs ###### Background - Brief Backstory: Raised in Vasrið’s Hollow as a child, but my parents died in a cave accident when I was 9. Lived with my close friend (Grazkul) until 12 (adult for orcs), and then moved to Każþarim for work in construction with him. I worked as a builder, and he worked as an architect.  - Where are you from?: Haramut area - Family (if any): None alive anymore ###### Personality - Personality Traits: Loyal, curious, stoic - Strengths: Ambitious - Weaknesses: Doesn’t know when to fold/give up - Likes: Gambling - Dislikes: Losing when gambling ###### Motivation - Main Goal: Find cause of the voices - Personal Quests (if any): N/A - What does your character fear most?: Losing a loved one - What would your character never do?: Betray/Deceive a friend ###### Interests - Hobbies: Gambling - Special Interests (magic, gods, creatures, etc.): Nature, since I grew up in caves and did not get to see nature much. - What would your character do in their free time?: Explore around new places ###### Relationships - Does your character have any connections to other party members?: N/A - Does your character have important NPC relationships?: Grazkul ###### Combat & Roleplay - Combat Style (frontline, ranged, magic, support): Frontline mage - Preferred Weapon/Spell Type: RNG based spells - How does your character react to danger?: Depends on if a friend may also be in danger. If a friend is in danger, we go all in. If I’m the only one in danger, attempt to escape. If escape doesn’t seem realistic, then try to fight by outsmarting/using violence as a last resort. - How does your character solve conflicts? (talk, fight, etc.): talking/negotiation before violence ###### Fun Extras - Unique quirks or habits: Always brings a coin and an ace up their sleeve for the gamba. If the voices tell me to do something, I will try my best to do it.
